title: Domain 2.1: Explain characteristics of routing technologies.
content:
🌐 Static Routing

Static routing involves manually configuring the routes that data takes to travel across a network. These routes are fixed and do not change unless manually updated by the network administrator.

Pro: Simple, no overhead from routing protocols.

Con: Not scalable and requires manual intervention for changes.

🚀 Dynamic Routing

Dynamic routing uses routing protocols to automatically adjust the paths that data takes based on real-time network conditions (such as link failures). These protocols discover optimal paths dynamically.

Pro: Scalable and adaptable to network changes.

Con: More complex and may have overhead from protocol exchanges.

🛰️ Routing Protocols

Border Gateway Protocol (BGP)

BGP is a path vector protocol used for routing between autonomous systems (AS) on the internet. It's the protocol that powers inter-domain routing (between different networks).

Common use: Internet routing.

Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP)

EIGRP is an advanced distance-vector protocol that combines the advantages of both link-state and distance-vector routing protocols. It is mainly used within a single AS.

Common use: Cisco networks, where ease of configuration is required.

Open Shortest Path First (OSPF)

OSPF is a link-state routing protocol used for routing within an AS. It builds a map of the network and dynamically determines the best path to a destination.

Common use: Large enterprise networks due to its scalability and efficiency.

🛠️ Route Selection Criteria

Administrative Distance

Administrative distance is a value used to rate the trustworthiness of a routing protocol. Lower values indicate higher trust.

Example: OSPF has an administrative distance of 110, while EIGRP has 90 (more trusted).

Prefix Length

The prefix length (also known as subnet mask) determines the number of bits used for the network portion of an IP address.

Common use: To create subnets and define the network range for routing decisions.

Metric

A metric is a value used by routing protocols to determine the "cost" of a route. Lower metrics are preferred as they indicate a better or shorter route.

Common use: In OSPF, metrics are based on link speed; in EIGRP, metrics are based on bandwidth and delay.

🔄 Address Translation

🔄 Network Address Translation (NAT)

NAT is used to map private IP addresses to a public IP address for communication over the internet. This allows multiple devices to share a single public IP address.

Common use: Home routers or corporate networks for secure internet access.

🔄 Port Address Translation (PAT)

PAT, also known as "overloading," allows multiple devices on a local network to share a single public IP address, but distinguishes between devices using port numbers.

Common use: Typically used in home and small business routers.

🔄 First Hop Redundancy Protocol (FHRP)

FHRP ensures that if a router goes down, another router can take its place and continue routing traffic, ensuring network reliability and availability.

Common use: In critical network environments for failover and redundancy.

🖥️ Virtual IP (VIP)

A virtual IP address is an IP address that is not tied to a specific physical interface. It can be assigned to multiple devices and moved between them for high availability.

Common use: Load balancing, failover, and high-availability configurations.

🖧 Subinterfaces

Subinterfaces allow a single physical network interface to act as multiple logical interfaces, each with its own IP address and subnet. This is useful for VLANs and routing between networks.

Common use: Used in routers to manage multiple VLANs or IP subnets over a single physical link.
